org.chrisjr.loom

Class Pattern

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.chrisjr.loom.Pattern
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Cloneable
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    ConcretePattern

    public class Pattern
extends Object
implements Cloneable
    The base class for patterns in Loom. A Pattern may either be: discrete, containing a non-overlapping series of events; continuous, its value a function of time; or compound, containing a combination of the two. A single pattern can only have one value at a time, and thus only a single mapping of a given type. However, by adding child patterns or creating a new Pattern using following(org.chrisjr.loom.Pattern), multiple mappings can be assigned.
    Author:
    chrisjr
    See Also:
    ConcretePattern

      • Pattern

        public Pattern(Loom loom,
       EventCollection events,
       ContinuousFunction function,
       boolean isConcrete)
        Creates a Pattern and adds itself to the Loom. Either a EventCollection or ContinuousFunction (not both) can be passed in, in which case it will create an underlying ConcretePattern.
        Parameters:
        loom - the Loom that holds this pattern (can be null)
        events - an EventCollection for the pattern
        function - a ContinuousFunction for the pattern
        isConcrete - is the pattern concrete (i.e. does it contain events/a function directly)

    • Method Detail

      • fromABC

        public static Pattern fromABC(Loom loom,
              String tune)
        Takes an ABC tune as input and creates a new pattern suitable for MIDI output. For a quick overview of ABC, see: . A minimal valid tune must contain three header lines: "X:" (a reference number), "T:" (a title) and "K:" (a key signature), followed by the notes. The key must be last; tempo, meter, and other headers are currently ignored. If the headers are omitted, the parser will do its best to add them appropriately. Examples: A rising scale in C natural minor: "K:Cm\nCDEF|GABc" The BACH motive (B-flat, A, C, B natural): "_BAc=B" Beginning to "Maria" from West Side Story: "C|^FG2C|(3^FGA(3^FGA|^FG2||"
        Parameters:
        loom - the Loom on which the new pattern should be created
        tune - a string containing a valid ABC tune
        Returns:
        a new pattern constructed from the tune

      • fromString

        public static Pattern fromString(Loom loom,
                 String string)
        Creates a new pattern using a numerical string, which will be turned into equally spaced events. Values are scaled to the maximum present in the string. Example: Pattern.fromString(loom, "024"); creates a pattern with three events, each 1/3 a cycle long, with values 0.0, 0.5, and 1.0.
        Parameters:
        loom - the Loom on which the new pattern should be created
        string - a string with digits
        Returns:
        a new pattern
        See Also:
        extend(String)

      • fromInts

        public static Pattern fromInts(Loom loom,
               Integer... ints)
        Creates a new pattern using a sequence of integers, which will be turned into equally spaced events. Values are scaled to the maximum present in the sequence. Example: Pattern.fromString(loom, 0, 2, 4); creates a pattern with three events, each 1/3 a cycle long, with values 0.0, 0.5, and 1.0.
        Parameters:
        loom - the Loom on which the new pattern should be created
        ints - the integer values for each event
        Returns:
        a new pattern with the specified events

      • following

        public static Pattern following(Pattern other)
        Create a new pattern that returns the same value as another. Useful for creating multiple mappings of the same type.
        Parameters:
        other - the pattern to follow
        Returns:
        a pattern that returns the same value as the specified pattern

      • extend

        public Pattern extend(String string)
        Extends the current pattern by treating the input as equally spaced events within a single cycle. For example, "01234" produces a set of 5 events, each 1/5 a cycle's duration, with values [0.0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0]. Values are scaled so that the maximum listed.
        Parameters:
        string - a string such as "10010010" describing a pattern to be tacked on at the end
        Returns:
        the updated pattern
        See Also:
        EventCollection.fromString(String)

      • extend

        public Pattern extend(Integer... ints)
        Extends the current pattern by treating the input as equally spaced events within a single cycle. For example, extend(0, 1, 2, 3, 4) will create 5 events, each 1/5 a cycle's duration, with values [0.0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1.0].
        Parameters:
        ints - the integer values of each event
        Returns:
        the updated pattern
        See Also:
        EventCollection.fromInts(Integer...)

      • extend

        public Pattern extend(LEvent... events)
        Extends the pattern by adding the events specified after the last event currently in the pattern. (If the pattern has no events yet, it will create a new EventCollection for this pattern and add the events to it.)
        Parameters:
        newEvents - the events to be appended
        Returns:
        the current pattern with events added
        See Also:
        extend(Collection)

      • getCurrentInterval

        public Interval getCurrentInterval()
        Returns the current interval from the perspective of this pattern, transformed by its time scale, offset, and loop interval (if applicable). Each pattern queries its parent, if it has one, or the Loom's scheduler if not; in this way, nested time transformations are possible.
        Returns:
        the current interval
        See Also:
        getCurrentInterval(boolean)

      • getCurrentInterval

        public Interval getCurrentInterval(boolean useOffset)
        Returns the current interval from the perspective of this pattern, transformed by its time scale, offset, and loop interval (if applicable). Each pattern queries its parent, if it has one, or the Loom's scheduler if not; in this way, nested time transformations are possible. If useOffset is false, it will ignore the time offset in its calculations. This is needed so that every(double, org.chrisjr.loom.transforms.Transform) and other functions act in the expected manner when a parent pattern is transformed.
        Parameters:
        useOffset - use the time offset when calculating interval
        Returns:
        a transformed interval
        See Also:
        transform(Interval, boolean)

      • transform

        public Interval transform(Interval interval)
        Performs the transformation of a given interval, according to the pattern's time scaling, offset, and loop interval.
        Parameters:
        interval - the interval to be transformed
        Returns:
        the transformed interval
        See Also:
        transform(Interval, boolean)

      • transform

        public Interval transform(Interval interval,
                 boolean useOffset)
        Performs the transformation of a given interval, according to the pattern's time scaling, offset, and loop interval. If useOffset is false, the offset will be ignored.
        Parameters:
        interval - the interval to be transformed
        useOffset - whether or not to use the offset
        Returns:
        the transformed interval

      • asInt

        public Pattern asInt(int lo,
            int hi)
        Set the mapping from this pattern's values to integers. The range from lo to hi is inclusive, so 1.0 will be mapped to hi; values are rounded to the nearest whole number using Math.round.
        Parameters:
        lo - the low end of the range
        hi - the high end of the range (inclusive)
        Returns:
        the current pattern

      • asMidiCommand

        public Pattern asMidiCommand(Integer... commands)
        Maps this pattern's values to the specified MIDI commands. Use -1 if a certain value should be a no-op. Example: asMidiCommand(-1, ShortMessage.NOTE_OFF, ShortMessage.NOTE_ON); maps the values 0.0, 0.5, and 1.0 (output from ConcretePattern.forEach(Pattern)) to the appropriate MIDI commands for each note.
        Parameters:
        commands - the commands to execute
        Returns:
        the current pattern

      • asMidiCommand

        public int asMidiCommand()
        Gets the current MIDI command for this pattern.
        Returns:
        the current MIDI command

      • asMidiCommand

      • asMidiChannel

        public Pattern asMidiChannel(Integer... channels)
        Sets the mapping of this pattern's values to MIDI channels. This can be used if you which to switch channels on certain notes, for example to create a Klangfarbenmelodie (or most likely, to render percussion on MIDI channel 10).
        Parameters:
        channels - the channels to map to
        Returns:
        the current pattern

      • asMidiChannel

      • asMidiData1

        public Pattern asMidiData1(int lo,
                  int hi)
        Maps the pattern's values to MIDI data byte 1. For NOTE_ON and NOTE_OFF messages, this is the note to be played (from 0 to 127).
        Parameters:
        lo - the low end of the range
        hi - the high end of the range (inclusive)
        Returns:
        the current pattern
        See Also:
        IntMapping

      • asMidiData1

        public int asMidiData1()
        Returns the current value of MIDI data 1.
        Returns:
        the current MIDI data 1 value

      • asMidiData1

        public int asMidiData1(Interval now)

      • asMidiNote

        public Pattern asMidiNote(Integer... values)
        Maps the values of this pattern to MIDI notes. Akin to asMidiData1(int, int), but output will be constrained to the possibilities specified. Useful to map to certain notes of the scale. Example: asMidiNote(60, 64, 67) will map the values 0.0, 0.5, and 1.0 to the notes middle C, E, and G. Other values will be floored (e.g. 0.25 => 60).
        Parameters:
        values - the notes to be mapped to
        Returns:
        the current pattern

      • asMidiNote

        public int asMidiNote()
        Returns the current MIDI note. An alias for asMidiData1(int, int).
        Returns:
        the current MIDI note

      • asMidiData2

        public Pattern asMidiData2(int lo,
                  int hi)
        Maps the pattern's values to MIDI data 2. For NOTE_ON and NOTE_OFF messages, this corresponds to the velocity.
        Parameters:
        lo - the low end of the range
        hi - the high end of the range (inclusive)
        Returns:
        the current pattern

      • asMidiData2

        public int asMidiData2()
        Returns the current MIDI data 2 value for this pattern.
        Returns:
        the current MIDI data 2 value

      • asMidiData2

        public int asMidiData2(Interval now)

      • asMidiMessage

        public Pattern asMidiMessage(Pattern notes)
        Maps the specified note pattern as a MIDI message, which will be Typically this will be called using the pattern itself as argument, i.e. notePattern.asMidiMessage(notePattern);
        Parameters:
        notes - the pattern that provides the MIDI notes (must have an asMidiData1(int, int) mapping).
        Returns:
        the current pattern
        See Also:
        asMidiMessage(Pattern, Pattern, Pattern, Pattern)

      • asMidiMessage

        public Pattern asMidiMessage(Pattern commands,
                    Pattern channels,
                    Pattern notes,
                    Pattern velocities)
        Maps the current pattern to MIDI messages and schedules them to be sent out using the Loom's MidiBusWrapper. A new message is sent each time there is an onset in the commands pattern. This takes four patterns as input (they need not be distinct). This allows each parameter of the MIDI message to be set separately if desired.
        Parameters:
        commands - the pattern that specifies the MIDI command
        channels - the pattern that specifies the MIDI channel
        notes - the pattern that specifies MIDI data 1
        velocities - the pattern that specifies MIDI data 2
        Returns:
        the current pattern

      • asOscMessage

        public Pattern asOscMessage(String addressPattern)
        Maps this pattern to an OSC message with a default argument of 1. Example: asOscMessage("/light") will result in a message of "/light 1".
        Parameters:
        addressPattern - the address to send the message to
        Returns:
        the current pattern
        See Also:
        asOscBundle(NetAddress, Pattern...)

      • asOscMessage

        public Pattern asOscMessage(String addressPattern,
                   int value)
        Maps this pattern to an OSC message with a single integer argument. Example: asOscMessage("/light", 1) will result in a message of "/light 1".
        Parameters:
        addressPattern - the address to send the message to
        value - the integer value
        Returns:
        the current pattern
        See Also:
        asOscBundle(NetAddress, Pattern...)

      • asOscMessage

        public Pattern asOscMessage(String addressPattern,
                   Mapping<?> mapping)
        Sets a mapping of this pattern to OSC messages, with a new Mapping used to provide the arguments. Example: asOscMessage("/light", new IntMapping(0, 1)); will call the IntMapping on the current pattern, then create a message like "/light 0" or "/light 1" depending on its value.
        Parameters:
        addressPattern - the address of the message
        mapping - the mapping from this pattern's values to the OSC message's arguments
        Returns:
        the current pattern

      • asOscMessage

        public Pattern asOscMessage(String addressPattern,
                   Pattern subPattern,
                   Mapping<?> mapping)
        Sets this pattern's mapping to OSC messages, using a second pattern subPattern to provide the values that will be translated into the message's arguments. The mapping will be called using the subpattern's current value when this pattern is queried. For example, the subpattern could have a mapping that turns 0.0 into the three floats [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] and 1.0 into the three floats [0.1, 0.2, 0.3], which would work independently of the values of the current pattern.
        Parameters:
        addressPattern - the address to send the message to
        subPattern - the pattern that will be used to provide the values for the mapping
        mapping - the mapping from subPattern's values to the OSC messages' arguments
        Returns:
        the current pattern

      • asOscMessage

        public OscMessage asOscMessage()
        Returns the current OSC message value of this pattern.
        Returns:
        the current OSC message

      • asOscBundle

        public Pattern asOscBundle(NetAddress remoteAddress)
        Sets a mapping to wrap up the OSC messages for this pattern's onsets into bundles and schedules them to be sent using the Loom's OscP5Wrapper. The current pattern's children are assumed to contain mappings to OSC messages.
        Parameters:
        remoteAddress - the server to send the messages to
        Returns:
        the current pattern
        See Also:
        asOscMessage(String, Mapping), asOscBundle(NetAddress, Pattern...)

      • asOscBundle

        public Pattern asOscBundle(NetAddress remoteAddress,
                  Pattern... patterns)
        Sets a mapping to wrap up the OSC messages for this pattern's onsets into bundles and schedules them to be sent using the Loom's OscP5Wrapper.
        Parameters:
        remoteAddress - the address of the OSC server to send to
        patterns - the patterns that contain the OSC messages to be bundled
        Returns:
        the current pattern

      • asOscBundle

        public OscBundle asOscBundle()
        Returns the pattern's value as an OSC bundle.
        Returns:
        the current OSC bundle

      • asSynthParam

        public Pattern asSynthParam(Synth synth,
                   String param,
                   float lo,
                   float hi)
        Sets a mapping from this pattern to the parameters of a supercollider.Synth object. Parameters vary depending on the synth in question; common ones might include "amp" and "gate".
        Parameters:
        synth - the supercollider.Synth object
        param - the name of the parameter
        lo - the low range of the value
        hi - the high range of the value
        Returns:
        the current pattern

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        the current pattern

      • asColor

        public Pattern asColor(int... colors)
        Set a mapping from the pattern's events to colors, blending between them using lerpColor in HSB mode.
        Parameters:
        colors - a list of colors to represent each state
        Returns:
        the updated pattern

      • selectFrom

        public Pattern selectFrom(Pattern... patterns)
        Creates a new pattern, using the current pattern as a selector to choose between the patterns provided as input. The output pattern will take on the values and mappings of its children, depending on this pattern's value.

        Let N be the number of input patterns. When this pattern is 0.0, the output pattern will return the values/mappings of its first child by default. When this pattern has a value of i/N, where i is a 1-based index into the input patterns, the output pattern will return the values and mappings of pattern i.

        Parameters:
        patterns - the patterns from which to select
        Returns:
        a new pattern

      • select

        public Pattern select(int i)

      • after

        public Pattern after(double time,
            Callable<Void> callable)
        Triggers the specified callback after a given amount of time. It will be added to a time-matched sibling pattern, so it will be affected by the time scale and offset of this pattern (but not its loop interval).
        Parameters:
        offset - the duration after which to trigger the callable
        callable - the callable to trigger
        Returns:
        the current pattern

      • after

        Parameters:

        callable - the callable to trigger
        Returns:
        the current pattern
